bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to G. Meredith Brill, April 21, 1948

div1.p: Hench discusses details concerning the upcoming publication of his Reed lecture for Alpha Omega Alpha in the society's magazine, the "Pharos."

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to G. Meredith Brill, April 21, 1948
div1.opener:
April 21, 1948
Mr. G. Meredith Brill
Managing Editor the Pharos
Slaterville Springs, New York
My dear Mr. Brill:
div1.p:
I have your letter of April 16, informing me that you plan to
publish the lecture on Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever, which
I gave at the University of Virginia, November 17, 1947, before the Alpha
Omega Alpha Chapter and the medical school faculty. I didn't know this
was being to you for publication. I was asked to send to the University
a couple of copies from which news items were made for the Alumni News, etc.
However, I shall be glad to have you publish it. The first five or six
pages have been “more or less” published elsewhere; namely, in Hygeia several
years ago but I have revised it somewhat since then so that it has not been
published exactly in this form and the last six pages have never been pub-
lished in any form. I was saving it for a later general publication but
since the circulation of the Pharos is limited and select, I don't believe
your use of it will interfere with its later publication. Incidentally what
is the circulation of the Pharos?

I don't know what copy you have, whether it was my preliminary type-
written copy or a mimeographed copy. I had about 30 requests for copies of
the talk after giving it at the University and had it mimeographed hastily.
Not intending it for publication, I did not concern myself about a few little
errors that I picked up but I am sending you herewith a corrected copy which
I should prefer you to use.

You request a cut or photo of Doctor Reed. I enclose two prints of
the conventional photograph of Reed. They aren't very good but they are all I
have at the moment as a great amount of my material is on loan at the Univer-
sity of Virginia Library and some more I have just sent to New York to the
Hall of Fame. May I suggest that you write to the editor of the University of
Virginia Alumni News. In their February 1948 issue they used a cut of Walter
Reed and will undoubtedly lend it to you. Should you wish to use a photograph
of the remains of Reed's famous “Building Number One” I can send you a print of
a photograph which I took just last month in Cuba.

I notice that you plan to send this to print almost immediately.
Would it be possible for me to read proof? I always like to do that with my
articles, otherwise almost always some small errors are perpetuated. If you
send it to me air mail, I promise to read it the night it comes and send it
back air mail the next day. Also, could I get some reprints, perhaps 200 or
300. They would be useful to me.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
